messageBody:
--- In junit@y..., Mike Clark <mike@c...> wrote:
> noneofyer42businessbub wrote:

> That's a subjective call. I've used both techniques successfully.

> > In other words, if I went with the new TestCase extension route, I'm not sure
> > whether I'll remember 6 months down the road that I created the new
TestCase
> > class to hold the custom assertions. Where as making calls to an specialized
> > Assert class route would likely to be more understandable.
> >
>
> Perhaps, if you remembered that the specialized Assert class existed.

Good point! If I'm not using that new specialized Assert class often enough I can
see myself forgetting about it's existence. As to which would be more
troublesome when forgotten (a new specialized Assert or a new common
TestCase base class) it's hard to say.

> > What are your thoughts on the matter of simplicity and readability vs. ease
of
> > initial implementation with regards to these choices? I'm trying to stick to
the
> > Extreme Programming way of doing things.
> >
>
> Do what's simplest for you today, then refactor it later if you change your
mind.
> Test code can begin to smell just as production code sometimes does.
Refactoring is
> the cure.
>
> Mike


--- In junit@y..., Vladimir Bossicard <vladimir@b...> wrote:
> I definitively stick with my approach even if it's maybe not the
> "Simplest thing which could possibly work". But it's maybe because I
> don't stick to this principle.
>
> In many cases, the simplest thing that works is #ifdef ... #endif (in
> C++). Well I let you imagine how a code may look like after several
> years of #ifdef... #endif!

I guess the question is what is simple?

Easy to implement now or simple to understand? They're not necessarily the
same thing.

It can come down to making a choice between the two. I suppose in those cases
the best thing to do at the moment is whatever hurts the least. At a certain
level what's simplest to implement becomes harder to comprehend.

Perhaps a three stage refactoring should occur when one feels the urge to
create a new specialized Assert class for one's new custom assert
responsibilities.

1. First keep the custom assert methods local to your test cases.

2. When excessive duplication starts to occur push these responsibilities up into
a new specialized Test Case base class and sub-class your individual unit test
cases from that.

3. When these assert methods have proven their usefulness and durability over
a period of time refactor them out into a new specialized sub-class Assert class
(and get rid of the specialized TestCase class) in order to make one's test code
a little easier to understand. Or shift these responsibilities to a new sub-class
Assert class when other unrelated tests cases could make use of them.

In other words, have these new custom assert methods evolve into a new
specialized Assert sub-class over a series of refactorings. Following the "You
Aren't Gonna Need It" principle.

Thanks for your advice,

Anthony
